show that the two correspondences we have set up are inverses.  This proves the Lemma. 
We note that if Ю is everywhere locally soluble then we may take a to be a factor of /); for if p is a simple prime factor of a not dividing D then the three terms in ( 5.  5 ) are all divisible by different powers of p and so the equation is impossible.  If a | D then we need only examine the solubility of ( 5.  5 ) in the reals and in those p-adic fields with p I 2i ); for the other fields it is trivially soluble.  Hence it is easy to find and similarly. 
If,  as in our previous paper,  we write 2 ^ for the number of elements of order 2 in the Tate-Safarevic group of so that 2 ^ is the order of then we can express ( 5.  2 )
and ( 5.  4 ) as follows :
Lemma 9.  Write 2 ^ for the order of and define Я ', AJ,  similarly.  Then we have
( 5.  6 ) + — 2,  g + ^^ A + Ai — 2. 
In proving this we have to split cases.  If Z ) is a rational square,  the order of G ^ is and the denominator of ( 5.  2 ) is 1 ; otherwise the order of is and the
denominator of ( 5.  2 ) is 2.  Similarly for ( 5.  4 ).
For historical reasons,  A + Aj — 2 is called the number of first descents ; it is easy to show directly that it is non-negative.  In general,  there need not be equality in the second equation ( 5.  6 ). We shall write G * for the group of those r-coverings of Pjj which can be lifted back to everywhere locally soluble 2-coverings,  and define A * by analogy with A ; similarly for Af.  Then
g t = A * + Ai — 2, 
and it may be shown by the methods of Cassels that A — A * is an even integer.  Since Fj ) and may have different Tate-Safarevic groups,  A — A * and A ^ — Af need not be equal ; we have many examples of this phenomenon. 
Most of the cases with g = 0 in Table 1 were obtained at once from Lemma 9 ; but when ^ > 0 for one of the curves Fj ) or F _^ j ^ it was necessary to do a further descent.  The next step is to find A *, and for this we use
Lemma 10.  Let ( 5.  5 ) be a v-cooering of Fj ^ which is everywhere locally soluble,  and let a,  T be rational numbers such that

Then there is a one-one correspondence between the elements of and the ways of

We know that ( 5.  7 ) is soluble ; for it is everywhere locally soluble by comparison with ( 5.  5 ). Now let be generic on the left-hand copy of Q in the diagram
